bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, February 22, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: ACKNOWLEDGED APR 10 1901 Bureau of Foreign Commerce

div1.p: INDEX BUREAU REC'D APR 6 '01 DEPT OF STATE.
No. 64. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia Feb'y 22, 1901
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. French merchants trying to divert Liberian trade from English and German to French markets.
No. 64. Consular Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia; Feb'y 22, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit, herewith, a "Consular," from F. Barnard Esq., a native of Martingique, a frenchman by birth; now a naturalized Liberian and Consul General for Santo Domingo. Liberian coffee is now selling, in this city, at 6 cts per pound, cash, and 8 cts trade. The present fright rates from Monrovia to Hamburg is £2. 5. 0, per ton.
Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General
Inclosure. 1. "Circular," 2. A letter to Hon. Thomas Morison, Chief Bureau of Accounts
CIRCULAR.

Messrs. Fraycinet and Company of Marseilles and Harve, France, eg to announce to the Liberian Coffee Farmers and the producers of African products generally, that the Company is prepared to do business with them on the markets where the very best prices will be assured them; and where their coffee will bring from $12 to $15 per cwt., and all other African produce will be sold on similar favorable terms.
Payments to be made in English coin or merchandise.
To facilitate the business their steamers will touch at Monrovia once in every two months and oftener if necessary.
Condition of freignt being £2 8s. 6d. per ton.
Communications and indents made in English if so desired.
For further particulars apply to
F. BARNARD,
at his office, Barnard's Hotel, No. 202, Broad Street, Monrovia. Monrovia, January 4, 1901.
